content.body: That's what I went with, after looking at other atom code elsewhere.  That tutorial was kinda sketchy in several ways.
hober, paul_irish: Feed up and validated.  http://www.xanthir.com/blog/atom/
TabAtkins: lookin great
TabAtkins, Google Reader doesn't seem to be creating links from the post's title.  Are the permalinks not in the feed?
AryehGregor: Ah, maybe not.  One sec.
AryehGregor: can you try it again?
Still doesn't seem to show up.
Maybe it's cached, though.
Wait, I'm doing it wrong.
Have you settled on "Tab Completion" for the Atom feed, or is that just your conversion script picking a random name each time you run it and then serving it indefinitely?
Try it now?
wonders how clients will cope with changing names
Settled on Tab Completion.
To avoid clients being weird with changing names.
Now Chrome's built-in feed display shows the links, but Reader still doesn't.  I'm guessing some type of caching.
Yeah, probably.
I bet Reader only does one request and uses the result for all users.  Would be silly otherwise.
(It would be fun to see how clients reacted to a feed changing name every time you refresh.  No rule against it, right?)
spent the last hour or something fighting the NYT's HTML5 FUD on Slashdot
Probably not worthwhile, ultimately, but I didn't feel like doing anything useful.
Also, yay, wide-screen layout on the main blog (where "wide" = "1000px")

The NYT article was incredibly pathetic.  Like: "The new Web language and its additional features present more tracking opportunities because the technology uses a process in which large amounts of data can be collected and stored on the user’s hard drive while online. Because of that process, advertisers and others could, experts say, see weeks or even months of personal data. That could include a user’s location, time zone, photographs,
text from blogs, shopping cart contents, e-mails and a history of the Web pages visited."  http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html
What the *heck*?
How could they have even made that *up*?
decides not to care.
It's extremely obvious that the report has no idea what they're talking about.  As usual.
AryehGregor: A slow news week, they need something to create news, even if they create it them selves.
it's also quite NIMBY style thing.
Looks like Mozilla is serious about getting pipelining to work: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=603503
Nice.
(At least assuming Patrick McManus is in a position to do anything about it.)
He seems to be a kernel hacker, not a Mozilla hacker.
he contributes to Mozilla
Judging by his blog, his kernel contributions look TCP-related, so pipelining sounds right up his alley.
Well, his blog is interesting.  I just read the whole history.  http://bitsup.blogspot.com/
goes to bed
TabAtkins: no feed autodiscovery?
where does http://bitbucket.org/ms2ger/dom-range/ allow me to actually see the spec?
Hixie: http://bitbucket.org/ms2ger/dom-range/raw/555ad6ae74fa/source.html ?
that seems to have content-disposition headers
but it'll do, thanks
anyone write arabic fluently here?
or hebrew?
Just when I thought HyBi couldn't get any worse, people started top posting
Hixie, can you modify that multipart algo so it's easier to invoke from outside of <form>? i.e. from FormData
yeah that seems reasonable. file a bug describing what interface you want and i'll make sure to make it available.
cool

Hixie: BTW on the subject of HyBi, it seems that NPN has difficult deployment issues e.g. there was some suggestion that it would make writing a server in java hard until some hypothetical future java release
So it seems to me that the compromise solution is the best option on the table at the moment
oh yes
or we could just update java
Unicode 6 adds support for emoji
unicode 6 has a fantastic set of new characters
i can't wait for fonts!
Hixie: You plan to ship Java 1.7 as part of WebSockets? That is... ambitious
at the current rate, it's unclear to me which will ship first
i know people are working on java 1.7 and making progress
it's unclear if the same can be said of websockets
phases of the moon have characters too
jgraham: (anyway you don't need a new java, just a new TLS library)
aah NY Times cannot spell HTML5
I see that article was already discussed...
I worry more about the less obvious means of tracking not discussed by the much cited EverCookie (or whatever it was called)
you mean they can't spell HTTP
the ones Björn mentioned
like DNS caching, fingerprinting, HTTP indeed, etc.
and we could probably reduce risk significantly, but then everything will be dogslow and legit stuff will stop working
we really should reduce fingerprinting, if only as an excuse to remove the crap from our HTTP requests like Accept-Encoding and whatnot
and to simplify the UA strings
Hixie: you pinged me
hsivonen: i did?
Hixie: well, yt'ed.
Hixie: The speed-to-spec-completion argument works heavily against NPN. NPN was just as controversial for the TLS people as WebSockets has been for HTTP people
hsivonen: ah yeah. i think i ended up asking the question on a bug.
Hixie: ok
I'm wondering if there's anything other than CSS and Web Apps that I should request observer status for
jgraham: controversy in a wg is imho irrelevant, what matters is whether UAs will implement.
for TPAC week, that is
Hixie, yeah, we're killing Accept-Encoding and some useless User-Agent bits for starters
in a way, I'm tempted to observe the TAG meeting
Hixie: The two may be somewhat related when you want changes on both clients and server sides
hsivonen, masochist? ;p
jgraham: in my experience, servers will implement whatever it takes to interop with the clients.
Since there is likely to be non-trivial overlap between the people who are unhappy and the implementors of major components
jgraham: (and precisely nothing more)
jgraham: (even if doing more is the right thing for future extensibility... which is why i'd specced the error handling differently in the old websockets drafts for client and server)
was http://www.0xdeadbeef.com/weblog/2010/10/websockets-shipping-before-its-ready/ mentioned here already?
I get called out for not prefixing in Opera's experimental release while Firefox 4 betas ship unprefixed too
until 7 days ago it wasn't even clear whether Mozilla was considering shipping a prefixed version judging from b.m.o
the decision is changing twice a week
way to wake up
he probably just misunderstood what you were shipping
well unless something changes our final will ship unprefixed too
we're not a market leader, we cannot really afford being incompatible
if Chrome et al were shipping with a prefixed version of some kind, so would we
are you actually shipping -76 or are you shipping the fixed version of -00 that's on the whatwg.org site and marked as obsolete?
oh, -00 I guess
I don't understand why he is talking about Opera
annevk: k
everyone seems to call it -76
yeah
dunno what chrome and safari actually implement
the problem is not the second or third browser doing something unprefixed, it's the first one
http://my.opera.com/core/blog/websockets -- "Opera supports version -00 of the protocol (aka -76). This is the same as Chrome 6, Safari 5.02 and Firefox 4 beta."
it'd be nice if there was a test suite online somewhere :-)
i thought -00 and -76 were the same version
they are
the question is whether it's -00 or -00-updated
confusingly called "-latest"
the version before ifette took over
we do the one with two types framing
k
so -00 then
probably with some of the fixes from "-latest"
man this is confusing
yes
and we have a test suite released, but you need to set it up
i hope ifette gets a spec out there soon
with the rate hybi is going through things, I don't have high hopes
i really just want us to do TLS-only at this point
with only wss:
why only wss?
i don't see the point of ws: if it's not trivial to implement
and we've clearly gone way past "trivial to implement"
i thought there was a use case of intermediaries being able to inspect the payload
It isn't at all clear to me that it is just as easy for a simple application using a prewritten server to use wss as ws
I would presume wss requires the author to care about certificates and complex stuff like that
Way too high a barrier to entry
zcorpan: i don't know of a real use case for that

jgraham: well we can add something to the API to disable cert checking if people think that that's useful. But I don't think a single 's' difference is enough of a red flag if we're going down that route, really.
Well it is exactly like http, which might not be ideal but has the advantage that people understand it
I don't think the right response to "we can't make it trivial" is "let's add loads of difficulty"
It is still trivial as long as someone else writes the code to do the handshake and decode the frames
Hixie: yeah, s/not/no was the difference. I didn't have a chance to add more info.
np thanks
i love that http://dev.w3.org/html5/html-xhtml-author-guide/html-xhtml-authoring-guide.html doesn't even remotely try to be polyglot
To be clear, I assume that no one advocating prefixing the websockets API expects it to have any effect other than as a "this is experimental" signal?
first two videos from #fronteers10: http://vimeo.com/channels/140223 first is from adactio on the Design of HTML5
annevk: any ideas on who christopher blizzard is?
annevk: because for supporting both -76 and -02 you don't need UA detection, just feature detection.
micheil: what you mean?
how do you do the feature detection?
well, the differences between the protocols is mainly in the protocol, not the DOM api.
er, how would you do the feature detection...
so there'd be a way to check based on data parsing
like we do with -75 and -76
ah, you mean on server side
if "sec-websocket-key3" in headers
(I've probably quoted that wrong)
yeah
the browser API's should be consistent
what about on client side
client side should be to spec.
api is the same, at least for now
as even with new handshaking, I can't see that changing.
the only recent major change was with subprotocol handling from what I can recall
with the change from DOMSring to DOMString or DOMString[]
ok it's way past my bed time
nn
although, JS defines that Array.toString = "item1,item2"
ah, that subprotocol handling, which is rather useless
which is how you need to declare if it's just a DOMString
(space separated to comma separated)
as for server side, detecting -02 may be harder then -75/76
micheil: Christopher Blizzard is a Mozilla guy. "Director of Evangelism at Mozilla Corporation" seems to be the full job title
k
he is now Director of Web Platform
http://www.0xdeadbeef.com/weblog/2010/07/new-role-at-mozilla-director-of-web-platform/
ah, okay
micheil: -02 has a Sec-WebSocket-Draft field (or whatever it's called)
so you can do feature detection with that then.
hasn't fully read -02 yet
Rik`: with FF, 3.6 doesn't declare the WebSocket constructor, does it?
i wonder if mozilla and webkit developers have tried to run our websocket testsuite yet
zcorpan: hmm?
micheil: we released a websocket testsuite. http://testsuites.opera.com/websockets/
(client)
yes, it tests the client aspect of the protocol (-00ish) and the api
zcorpan: ah, I know yahoo was doing similar.
micheil: pointer?
none. it was on the server side
non-released data
iirc.
oh
so, what do I need to run the tests?
you need pywebsocket, see README
micheil: right, there's nothing websocket related in 3.6
okay, I'm getting reports of "WebSocket" in window === true in 3.6.4
I just tested in 3.6.10
okay. odd.
3.6.4 is rather old btw
I'm being told: javascript:alert("WebSocket" in window)
is alert true
and javascript:alert(navigator.userAgent) in the same UA is?
turns out that a js library had created it for some reason.
oh
god
should not have emailed hybi
heh.
micheil: That is quite crazy
yeah, because this fallback implements a WebSocket object, by interfacing with flash, but doesn't define to the WebSocket DOM API
Hey, did you hear? HTML5 may weaken privacy! http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html
takes out his 2-by-4
(Not to mention that the article calls HTML5 a "new Web language"
Hmm... this same journalism appears to have written an article about Flash cookies, as well.
GPHemsley: it would be interesting to know what the quoted people said in full
hsivonen: they probably didn't say anything.
an unnamed source is as good as no source.
micheil: I'd expect the named sources to have said something somewhere.
http://www.smashingmagazine.com/2010/10/11/local-storage-and-how-to-use-it/
huh, chrome is switching to ws protocol v02
which is, I believe, very unstable
maybe they want to experiment with it in the dev channel?
Well it is kinda surprising. But they always claimed they would do this
So not all that surprising
yeah i'm not surprised :)
It will be interesting to see what effect it has, if any, on the adoption of websockets
i wonder what microsoft are doing
they reviewed -02
It will be intersting to see what they do in IE9
If they do nothing they might just have to follow everyone in IE10
Or they might not. Depends on how it plays out, really
smaug____: got a link re: ws protocol v02 ?
see hybi email archives
claim by Ian Fette
thx
but per data from Peter` I guess that won't make it in before Chrome 8
hober: How do I get autodiscovery?  I'll turn it on if I know how.
wonders if your IE shirt comes holes or patches
really wishes there were some IRC channel, or some other relatively low-lag forum, where people from all the major browsers/engines, hung out for quick technical discussion
jwalden: Dude, what?
TabAtkins: I'm thinking of one specific engine, really
Which is...?
umm, IE?
Okay then.  So why does your desire for IE engineers to get on IRC result in you spamming the room with a generic request that seems to be satisfied by this very room?
...wait, you think that was spam?
It was the second time you said it.  ^_^
oh, sorry
I thought the first time I'd pinged out and it hadn't made its way to the channel
in my defense I checked http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20101012 to see whether it had made its way here, didn't see it

GPHemsley: The "New Web Code" and "Web [Markup] Language" bothers me too, but I think the article has a good point about the possibilities that providing 256 times larger storage than cookies for advertising networks IS going to be a privay issue.
And the storage is an SQLite DB, which requires special tools or libraries to view or modify. I think users should have easy to use tools for managing the cookies and local storage databases.
I think I'll make a tool, because the tracking cookies have also bothered me for a long time. The interface that for eg. Safari provides is not useful enough to really manage them
I want to select cookies based on values or regexpes and remove or filter based on keywords aobut sites or values. And if the values are base64 I want the tool to decode them.
At least browser should ask the user if they want to allow different sites to store a database.
I am very excited about the opportunities that local storage provides for web development, but I am also concerned about privacy issues.
Why does the storage size matter? If you have, say, 8 bytes, then you can store a unique ID on the client and store arbitrary amounts of data on a server indexed by ID
have a SGI t-shirt with holes eaten by my little sister's hamster. ;-)
Storing more data on the client doesn't seem any more privacy-violating
Philip`: It matters, because it will be easier to store long log of events about users. Think of it as a way to provide 1 user ID + 255 event IDs...
I mean, it provides more opportunities for advertisers also, and you know they are creative people. :-)
Why would they store it on the client anyway? That info could get lost any time
All you need to store on the client is the identifying marker, so you know who to send data on behalf of
The privacy issues by local storage may not be that different from cookies, but I think it is important that this issue is being discussed properly instead of just ridiculing the whole issue.
I don't think anyone is ridiculing it
You shouldn't focus on the storage size, the "harder to remove" bit is more important
I was going to end the last message with "instead of ridiculing a poor journalist trying to make sense of the new things about HTML 5."
Workshiva: I agree. The size may not be that important, but values in SQLite DBs are harder to remove and manage without proper tools.
Even so, I think browsers will offer good tools to clean out the new storage forms quickly enough
I'm more worried about flash sharedobjects (still)
I just watched the Crockford Javascript Series and he makes some good points on part 6 about HTML5 worsening the XSS and some other security issues.
I'll refrain from discussing Crockford :)
Me too - although they are sandboxed, but with Adobe's recent security track record it makes me worry a little. Just found them out on my computer.
peterhil: you'd think if he had good points he'd have mentioned them on the mailing list rather than keeping them to his talks. :-)
I haven't watched the mailing lists. But it's a shame if it is so.

I learned the intricacies of encoding UTF-8 this summer, and it made me realize how there is a gazillion variations on how to encode, comment or escape data using different web and internet technologies, all bound or interwoven to the markup language used. So the only place to solve the problem is the markup language.

I mean you can't regexp for malicious code in base64 encoded data for example. Not to mention how to misencode information between language encodings and the Unicode. It let's you quite easily produce hard to detect malicious scripting tags, which can slip through form validation.
Usually the scurity measures by frameworks prevent this, but there are a lot of misconfigured servers...
And I haven't experimented how easy it is to make such script injections, but I believe I could easily make one if I wanted.
Umm, what makes the client side storage for cookies any more user-servicable than other storage mechanisms?
In either case the values on disk could be stored in any format you like (sqlite, mork, RDF, encrypted key-value pairs)
You rely on the browser to provide a magement UI
*management
I guess The SQL stuff lends itself more to a client side database for acceptable performance. But that need not be worse than the other formats
And it is mostly defunct
in some ways, storage or SQL are more restricted than cookies, since you need a browsing context from your origin to read or write
unlike cookies, where any resource load, even just an image, can read and write it in principle
annevk: so what are we doing for the non-visual scrollIntoView() stuff?
Hixie: Would it be possible to get a WOFF reference into Acid3?
Hixie: Like, replacing SVG Fonts or something?
if you got all the browser vendors to co-sign a publicly archived e-mail to me requesting that, and providing an example of what the new test would be, then sure
but i'd much rather not change acid3
I'm on it.
(get howcome to ok it too while you're at it)
Hixie: Out of curiousity, did you apply this criteria to the recent change about :visited?
not the publicly archived part, but the change was much more minor
and could have been spun much worse
("acid3 forces browsers to violate user's privacy")
here the spin danger is in the other direction ("acid3 author caves to pressure from microsoft, improves IE9's score by removing subtests already passed by other browsers")
All right, but WOFF is the only font format that everyone actually agrees to support, as opposed to SVG Fonts, which some browsers have explicitly stated they *won't* support.
Um, TrueType is already supported by everyone :-)
Caves to pressure from WebFonts WG!
(WOFF is a waste of time IMHO, given TrueType, but that's a side issue)
i'm not disagreeing with you that we shouldn't have added SVG Fonts to the test
Well, I'll get the WebFontsWG to request it.  We've got everyone but Apple represented.
i don't think a wg should request it
wgs requesting things is how we got into this problem in the first place
just get the browser vendors to co-sign an e-mail
(and howcome to agree)
if there's actual support for this then it shouldn't be hard
(personally i'm not convinced there is)
It's easy to coordinate the action within the WG, simply because we have 4 browsers there.  Including howcome.
opera doesn't support woff (yet)
i don't mind where you talk about it, i just mean that the e-mail shouldn't mention the wg
it's a PR thing
Arrggh, I really hate the multi-process safety measure of Chromium (Chrome).
Opera and Firefox work just as well, without that long list of processess.

TabAtkins: i know sylvain doesnt like the existing @font-face test because the Ahem font doesnt have its installable bit set to whatever IE9 needs.. so they fail. At the same time, woff does seem more 'web standard' than a ttf..
Exactly.  There's no standard specifying that TTF must be supported, so it kinda sucks.
